thread.title: Leicester law firm Spearing Waite oversaw record £300m of corporate transactions last year

author: Tom Pegden
title: Leicester law firm Spearing Waite oversaw record £300m of corporate transactions last year

A Leicester law firm has announced that it oversaw a record £300 million worth of corporate transactions last year. 
The team at Spearing Waite, in Pocklingtons Walk, said revenues for its corporate practice were up a fifth in 2017. 
The firm advised on more than 30 transactions during 2017 including a £24 million acquisition for pizza delivery giant Dominos, a management buyout for Nottingham-based energy technology firm ENSEK and an initiative to raise £75 million of venture capital funding. 
The Its corporate team also advised global technology group Freudenberg on its acquisition of a precision moulding company in Lancashire. 
Other transactions included the sale of Clear & Lane accountants, in Leicester’s Melton Road, to Warwickshire-based Magma Chartered Accountants. 
Jahid Ali, head of corporate at Spearing Waite, said: “2017 was a record year for our corporate team and the quantity and quality of the deals completed in those 12 months are testament to our growing reputation. Spearing Waite moved to Pocklingtons Walk in 2015 
“The majority of the deals were acquisitions or investments – we are delighted that so many of our clients continue to enjoy strong growth despite the often-cited uncertainty around Brexit. 
“The ENSEK management buy-out and Magma’s acquisition of Clear & Lane are great examples of successful businesses investing further in the East Midlands.” 
Martin Smith, a member of the management board at Spearing Waite, said: “Our move to Pocklingtons Walk in 2015 has been instrumental to our growth strategy which has enabled us to keep on providing top quality legal advice to existing and new clients. “Spearing Waite continues to benefit from the recruitment of experienced associates and partners, many of whom joined us from large national and international practices where they felt stifled and unable to provide the kind of personal, bespoke service their clients deserved. Read More
